title: Equivalent resistance - Rx current - Rvar changes

content.question: The figure shows a circuit that contains a battery and four resistors <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="R sub variable" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Var</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Resistors <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="R sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> are fixed resistors with the same resistance <math alttext="R sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>0</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Resistor <math alttext="R sub variable" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Var</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is a variable resistor with an initial resistance setting of <math alttext="2 R sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The resistance of <math alttext="R sub variable" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Var</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is then changed to <math alttext="the fraction R sub 0, over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>. When <math alttext="R sub variable" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>Var</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> decreases to <math alttext="the fraction R sub 0, over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>, does the current <math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> in resistor <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>R</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> increase or decrease, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> increases. The equivalent resistance of the three parallel resistors decreases.

<math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> increases. The equivalent resistance of the three parallel resistors is less than each individual resistance.

<math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> decreases. The equivalent resistance of the three parallel resistors decreases.

<math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> decreases. The equivalent resistance of the three parallel resistors is less than each individual resistance.

content.answer: <math alttext="I sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> increases. The equivalent resistance of the three parallel resistors decreases.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
